description:
Aspergillus homomorphus CBS 101889 is a species of filamentous fungus belonging to the genus Aspergillus. It was first isolated from a soil sample collected in France.

Morphologically, A. homomorphus produces conidiophores (asexual reproductive structures) that are smooth and have a vesicle (swollen structure) at the apex. The conidial heads (clusters of asexual spores) are typically biseriate, meaning the conidiophore bears two layers of phialides (spore-bearing structures). The conidia (asexual spores) are globose (spherical) in shape and smooth-walled.

Genetically, A. homomorphus is characterized by its unique DNA sequence, particularly in the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region, which is commonly used for fungal species identification. Phylogenetic analyses have placed A. homomorphus within the Aspergillus section Fumigati, which includes several medically relevant species.

The ecological role and potential applications of A. homomorphus are not well-studied, as it is a relatively recently described species. Further research may elucidate its potential significance in the environment or potential biotechnological uses.
